_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Relief header and freezer area detection

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
oods has updated a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed.  
¿	Compliance Audit - Olympia Foods has updated a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Olympia Foods PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  An initial compliance audit will be conducted by July 28, 2015.   
¿	Hot Work Permits - Olympia Foods has updated a best management practice for hot work.  Olympia Foods updated their hot work permit procedures for the refrigeration system during July 2015.  
 

VII.	Five-Year Accident History
The Olympia Foods facility has not yet charged the ammonia refrigeration system and therefore has not experienced an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 

VIII.	Emergency Response Program
Olympia Foods has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release.  

Upon facility start-up, Olympia Foods will communicate and train facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and will interact (i.e. onsite inspections) with the Franklin Park Fire Department. 
 
Upon facility start-up, Olympia Foods will coordinate their ERP with the Franklin Park Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing the agency with

a copy of our ERP, and providing a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with Franklin Park Fire Department personnel to discuss the facilities operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with Franklin Park Fire Department personnel.

Olympia Foods' maintenance department will have designated personnel responsible for investigating and assisting the Franklin Park Fire Department (if necessary) with response to accidental releases of ammonia. 

The facility has two (2) windsocks onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.  

The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 

IX.	Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.
 

X.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Olympia Foods' operations. Olympia Foods is currently implementing their Process Safety Management Program. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Olympia Foods.  

XI.	Management Program
Olympia Foods has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Darrell Herman, Plant Engineer, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.

ns and ensures they are properly maintained.  Olympia Foods developed initial operating procedures for the refrigeration system during June-July 2015.  Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate.
¿	Training - Olympia Foods has updated a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.
¿	Management of Change - Olympia Foods has updated a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented.  
¿	Pre-Startup Review - Olympia Foods has updated a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI. 
 

¿	Mechanical Integrity - Olympia Foods has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Olympia Foods formalized maintenance procedures for the refrigeration system during July 2015.
¿	Contractor Qualifications - Olympia Foods has updated a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Olympia Foods and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency response plan and control over entrance into process areas.  
¿	Incident Investigation - Olympia F

mergency Action and Response Plan (EARP) that contains procedures designed to maximize the safety of all employees, contractors, and visitors in the event of an emergency and also guard against environmental consequences. 

III.	Facility Identification
The Olympia Foods facility is located at 9501 Nevada Avenue in Franklin Park, Illinois.  Olympia Foods is a producer of raw and pre-cooked gyro meats, as well as pita and flatbreads.   

The NAICS code for the facility is 311812.  A large portion of the facility is refrigerated food processing and to preserve products for distribution.   

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one (1) refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating processing areas, coolers and freezers in the facility. 

The total amount of ammonia being charged to the refrigeration system is approximately 22,000 pounds.  The refrigeration system will be charged in two (2) phases. The initial charge will be to the low temperature system, and is anticipated at approximately 10,000 pounds. The remainder of the ammonia charge will be added to the system at a later date. 

An aerial map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. 

IV.	Hazard Assessment - Worse Case Scenarios (WCS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the worst-case scenario.  Appendix C consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the worse case release scenario. 

V.	Hazard Assessment - Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS)
Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternative release scenario.  Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 

VI.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the O

SHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The first audit of the PSM program will occur by July 28, 2015, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
 

¿	Employee Participation - Olympia Foods has updated a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
¿	Process Safety Information - Olympia Foods maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed and updated as of July 21, 2015.
¿	Process Hazard Analysis - Olympia Foods has updated a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Olympia Foods conducted a thorough, initial, PHA study for the refrigeration system during July 2015.  
¿	Operating Procedures - Olympia Foods has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operatio
